blog.name: secretlyatargaryen
blog.title: Worms are crawling in and out of Rhaegar's ass
blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: One of my favorite forgotten Tyrion quotes about Shae is “She deserved better than what he had to give her.” Which comes after...
body:
One of my favorite forgotten Tyrion quotes about Shae is “She deserved better than what he had to give her.” Which comes after Tyrion is forced into the marriage with Sansa and right before Joffrey’s wedding, when Tyrion is thinking about his dubious place at court and considering finding something better for Shae before things become worse for him under Joffrey’s reign. And this quote becomes terrifyingly true when Tyrion later murders Shae, but it also tells the reader that one of Tyrion’s main problems with his relationships with women is that he thinks he has nothing worthy to give.

And this of course has a lot to do with his disability and the ableism he’s internalized by years of abuse and being told that the only thing of value about him is his Lannister name, and it comes up again when he interacts with Penny.

When Tyrion rejects Penny’s kiss, he thinks about how he doesn’t want to hurt her, but he ALSO thinks about how she doesn’t really want him.

This was nothing he had wanted. He liked Penny, he pitied Penny, he even admired Penny in a way, but he did not desire her. He had no wish to hurt her, though; the gods and his sweet sister had given her enough pain. So he let the kiss go on, holding her gently by the shoulders. His own lips stayed firmly shut. The Selaesori Qhoran rolled and shuddered around them.Finally she pulled back an inch or two. 

Tyrion could see his own reflection shining in her eyes. Pretty eyes, he thought, but he saw other things as well. A lot of fear, a little hope … but not a bit of lust. She does not want me, no more than I want her.

For once, Tyrion is in the position to be on the receiving end of someone else’s affection, and he feels bad that he can’t return it, but also thinks that she can’t really want anything he has to offer her. Penny actually has the same insecurities about her own body.

“Are you a maid, Penny?”

She blushed. “Yes. Of course. Who would have—”

“Stay that way. Love is madness, and lust is poison. Keep your maidenhead. You’ll be happier for it, and you’re less like to find yourself in some dingy brothel on the Rhoyne with a whore who looks a bit like your lost love.”

Penny also has internalized ableism about her own body and I think she thinks that Tyrion might be safer to express affection for because he is also a dwarf. Penny’s also probably had more friendly and loving interactions with other dwarfs than with able bodied people so she probably feels more comfortable with Tyrion than an able bodied person, who she thinks would “of course” reject her.

Tyrion, on the other hand, has never met another dwarf and feels uncomfortable around her because she reminds him of his own vulnerabilities, and that’s part of the reason he rejects her. He’s also thinking in the above quote about love in general in a very cynical way, as something false and untrustworthy and unattainable.

But he also thinks Penny does not find him physically attractive (nor does she feel that way about herself) and so he thinks that he has nothing worthy to give her. He can’t please her physically and he can’t meet her emotional needs, but he DOES think about how she deserves something better.

The girl deserves better than a pig, he thought. An honest kiss, a little kindness, everyone deserves that much, however big or small.

Tyrion is talking about Penny but I think he’s also on some level talking about himself, although I don’t think he quite makes the leap from “she deserves better” to “I deserved better.” He doesn’t think of himself as someone who can give love or even kindness, and when he’s thinking about his kindness towards Penny he thinks of it as a lie.

Sometimes he envied the girl all her pretty little dreams. She reminded him of Sansa Stark, the child bride he had wed and lost. Despite the horrors Penny had suffered, she remained somehow trusting. She should know better. She is older than Sansa. And she’s a dwarf. She acts as if she has forgotten that, as if she were highborn and fair to look upon, instead of a slave in a grotesquerie. At night Tyrion would oft hear her praying. A waste of words. If there are gods to listen, they are monstrous gods who torment us for their sport. Who else would make a world like this, so full of bondage, blood, and pain? Who else would shape us as they have? Sometimes he wanted to slap her, shake her, scream at her, anything to wake her from her dreams. No one is going to save us, he wanted to scream at her. The worst is yet to come. Yet somehow he could never say the words. Instead of giving her a good hard crack across that ugly face of hers to knock the blinders from her eyes, he would find himself squeezing her shoulder or giving her a hug. Every touch a lie. I have paid her so much false coin that she half thinks she’s rich.

I think Tyrion actually does love Penny on some level, but he doesn’t realize it because he thinks that he isn’t in a position to give her that honest kiss. Tyrion thinks similarly about Sansa when he’s forced to marry her.

“Don’t lie, Sansa. I am malformed, scarred, and small, but …” she could see him groping “… abed, when the candles are blown out, I am made no worse than other men. In the dark, I am the Knight of Flowers.” He took a draught of wine. “I am generous. Loyal to those who are loyal to me. I’ve proven I’m no craven. And I am cleverer than most, surely wits count for something. I can even be kind. Kindness is not a habit with us Lannisters, I fear, but I know I have some somewhere. I could be … I could be good to you.”

A lot of this is because of his disability but it’s also because Tyrion is an abuse victim who doesn’t know how to either give or receive kindness. He automatically assumes that any kind words Sansa gives to him are lies and also assumes his kindness towards her is a lie as well.

“Sansa, is aught amiss?” He spoke without thinking, and instantly felt the fool. All her kin are slaughtered and she’s wed to me, and I wonder what’s amiss.

Of course Tyrion is right to know that he can’t make things better for Sansa because of WHO he is and her position as a Lannister hostage and a child who should not be in this position in the first place, but he also attributes it in part to the fact that he’s disabled. Which isn’t incorrect either because Sansa IS repulsed by his disability, and that makes Tyrion withdraw further, even though Sansa does try to be kind to Tyrion and isn’t quite as ableist as Tyrion expects her to be. But Tyrion doesn’t blame Sansa for this, he assumes her ableism as a state of fact, because he’s been raised to expect nothing less, just like Penny. Of course, who would have - 

So, when people say that Tyrion “expects” things from women, I think it’s rather the opposite. I think Tyrion expects very little when it comes to how other people see him, and this makes it difficult for him to both give and receive affection. What we should be saying instead is that Tyrion should expect more. He should expect more than this:

“Be certain that you tell her who I am, and warn her of what I am.“ Jyck had not always troubled to do that. There was a look the girls got in their eyes sometimes when they first beheld the lordling they’d been hired to pleasure … a look that Tyrion Lannister did not ever care to see again.

He should expect more than that women need to be warned that he’s disabled. He shouldn’t be treating it as a given that people are repulsed by his appearance. This doesn’t mean he’s owed sex or love or anything, but he’s absolutely right to feel angry and hurt about ableism and he SHOULD be expecting more, and so should the fandom.

And this quote becomes terrifyingly true when Tyrion later murders Shae, but it also tells the reader that one of Tyrion’s main problems with his relationships with women is that he thinks he has nothing worthy to give.

And this of course has a lot to do with his disability and the ableism he’s internalized by years of abuse and being told that the only thing of value about him is his Lannister name, and it comes up again when he interacts with Penny.

When Tyrion rejects Penny’s kiss, he thinks about how he doesn’t want to hurt her, but he ALSO thinks about how she doesn’t really want him.

This was nothing he had wanted. He liked Penny, he pitied Penny, he even admired Penny in a way, but he did not desire her. He had no wish to hurt her, though; the gods and his sweet sister had given her enough pain. So he let the kiss go on, holding her gently by the shoulders. His own lips stayed firmly shut. The Selaesori Qhoran rolled and shuddered around them.Finally she pulled back an inch or two. 

Tyrion could see his own reflection shining in her eyes. Pretty eyes, he thought, but he saw other things as well. A lot of fear, a little hope … but not a bit of lust. She does not want me, no more than I want her.

For once, Tyrion is in the position to be on the receiving end of someone else’s affection, and he feels bad that he can’t return it, but also thinks that she can’t really want anything he has to offer her. Penny actually has the same insecurities about her own body.

“Are you a maid, Penny?”

She blushed. “Yes. Of course. Who would have—”

“Stay that way. Love is madness, and lust is poison. Keep your maidenhead. You’ll be happier for it, and you’re less like to find yourself in some dingy brothel on the Rhoyne with a whore who looks a bit like your lost love.”

Penny also has internalized ableism about her own body and I think she thinks that Tyrion might be safer to express affection for because he is also a dwarf. Penny’s also probably had more friendly and loving interactions with other dwarfs than with able bodied people so she probably feels more comfortable with Tyrion than an able bodied person, who she thinks would “of course” reject her.

Tyrion, on the other hand, has never met another dwarf and feels uncomfortable around her because she reminds him of his own vulnerabilities, and that’s part of the reason he rejects her. He’s also thinking in the above quote about love in general in a very cynical way, as something false and untrustworthy and unattainable.

But he also thinks Penny does not find him physically attractive (nor does she feel that way about herself) and so he thinks that he has nothing worthy to give her. He can’t please her physically and he can’t meet her emotional needs, but he DOES think about how she deserves something better.

The girl deserves better than a pig, he thought. An honest kiss, a little kindness, everyone deserves that much, however big or small.

Tyrion is talking about Penny but I think he’s also on some level talking about himself, although I don’t think he quite makes the leap from “she deserves better” to “I deserved better.” He doesn’t think of himself as someone who can give love or even kindness, and when he’s thinking about his kindness towards Penny he thinks of it as a lie.

Sometimes he envied the girl all her pretty little dreams. She reminded him of Sansa Stark, the child bride he had wed and lost. Despite the horrors Penny had suffered, she remained somehow trusting. She should know better. She is older than Sansa. And she’s a dwarf. She acts as if she has forgotten that, as if she were highborn and fair to look upon, instead of a slave in a grotesquerie. At night Tyrion would oft hear her praying. A waste of words. If there are gods to listen, they are monstrous gods who torment us for their sport. Who else would make a world like this, so full of bondage, blood, and pain? Who else would shape us as they have? Sometimes he wanted to slap her, shake her, scream at her, anything to wake her from her dreams. No one is going to save us, he wanted to scream at her. The worst is yet to come. Yet somehow he could never say the words. Instead of giving her a good hard crack across that ugly face of hers to knock the blinders from her eyes, he would find himself squeezing her shoulder or giving her a hug. Every touch a lie. I have paid her so much false coin that she half thinks she’s rich.

I think Tyrion actually does love Penny on some level, but he doesn’t realize it because he thinks that he isn’t in a position to give her that honest kiss. Tyrion thinks similarly about Sansa when he’s forced to marry her.

“Don’t lie, Sansa. I am malformed, scarred, and small, but …” she could see him groping “… abed, when the candles are blown out, I am made no worse than other men. In the dark, I am the Knight of Flowers.” He took a draught of wine. “I am generous. Loyal to those who are loyal to me. I’ve proven I’m no craven. And I am cleverer than most, surely wits count for something. I can even be kind. Kindness is not a habit with us Lannisters, I fear, but I know I have some somewhere. I could be … I could be good to you.”

A lot of this is because of his disability but it’s also because Tyrion is an abuse victim who doesn’t know how to either give or receive kindness. He automatically assumes that any kind words Sansa gives to him are lies and also assumes his kindness towards her is a lie as well.

“Sansa, is aught amiss?” He spoke without thinking, and instantly felt the fool. All her kin are slaughtered and she’s wed to me, and I wonder what’s amiss.

Of course Tyrion is right to know that he can’t make things better for Sansa because of WHO he is and her position as a Lannister hostage and a child who should not be in this position in the first place, but he also attributes it in part to the fact that he’s disabled. Which isn’t incorrect either because Sansa IS repulsed by his disability, and that makes Tyrion withdraw further, even though Sansa does try to be kind to Tyrion and isn’t quite as ableist as Tyrion expects her to be. But Tyrion doesn’t blame Sansa for this, he assumes her ableism as a state of fact, because he’s been raised to expect nothing less, just like Penny. Of course, who would have - 

So, when people say that Tyrion “expects” things from women, I think it’s rather the opposite. I think Tyrion expects very little when it comes to how other people see him, and this makes it difficult for him to both give and receive affection. What we should be saying instead is that Tyrion should expect more. He should expect more than this:

“Be certain that you tell her who I am, and warn her of what I am.“ Jyck had not always troubled to do that. There was a look the girls got in their eyes sometimes when they first beheld the lordling they’d been hired to pleasure … a look that Tyrion Lannister did not ever care to see again.

He should expect more than that women need to be warned that he’s disabled. He shouldn’t be treating it as a given that people are repulsed by his appearance. This doesn’t mean he’s owed sex or love or anything, but he’s absolutely right to feel angry and hurt about ableism and he SHOULD be expecting more, and so should the fandom.

summary: Imagine Sansa Stark and Jon Snow staying up with you after a nightmare.
title: Imagine Sansa Stark and Jon Snow staying up with you after a nightmare.
body:
The cold air blew through the window as soon as it was opened, and little snowflakes danced their way into the room. The drop in temperature was the first thing that you had noticed, and the second was that you were not alone in your bed. Feeling weight sink down next to you, you went for the attack before you opened your eyes. Your wrists were grabbed by a strong hand in the other direction, which made you pause and open your eyes. The hand was warm, in your dreams they had always been cold -

Jon Snow’s milk-chocolate eyes stared into yours. He loosened his grip around your wrist and finally, let your hands drop onto your stomach. They weren’t there long. The elegant hands of Lady Sansa took hold of them. She was the one who you had tried to attack, you realized.

“I’m so sorry, Sansa.” You said, feeling your cheeks flare up.

“You were having a nightmare.” She said, looking over at Jon. “We could hear you screaming from our rooms. When we found you, you were burning up.”

You took a couple of deep breaths, and attempted to wipe your sweaty forehead with the pillow. “I’m okay, really. Just a bad dream.” You attempted to reassure.

“We’d better stay just in case. The others might not be so happy if you wake them up again.” Jon said, sitting on the bed beside you.

summary: Dear Dany Antis...
body:
Dear Dany Antis…

I get it. I used to be the exact same way. And Dany still isn’t my *favourite* character…

But my issue comes with the reasons that Antis tend to give for their hatred of Dany. Things along the lines of “She’s not a hero, she’s an antagonist and is going to turn into a villain because she did x, y, and z”.

You’re right. She isn’t a “hero” at least in terms of our perception of what a hero is. Most people look at typical fairytales and how stories normally write protagonists. They’re good no matter what, they’re perfect, they are the recievers of everything good in the world. But those protagonists are not HUMAN.

GRRM said himself that he intends to write morally grey characters because we are human and we are all “grey”.

“In order to get inside their skin, I have to identify with them. That includes even the ones who are complete bastards, nasty, twisted, deeply flawed human beings with serious psychological problems. Even them. When I get inside their skin and look out through their eyes, I have to feel a certain — if not sympathy, certainly empathy for them. I have to try to perceive the world as they do, and that creates a certain amount of affection.”

“Grey characters have always interested me the most and I think the world is full of them. I read a lot of history, and I don’t see any purely heroic characters or purely evil characters.”

“Conversely you can read stories about all the saints from Catholic history and Mother Theresa or Ghandi and you can find things about them that were flawed or questionable actions that they undertook.”

“We’re all grey and I think we all have the capacity in us to do heroic things and very selfish things. I think understanding that is how you create characters that really have some depth to them.”

Dany is not MEANT to be perfect and she’s not MEANT to be completely evil. She’s meant to be a HUMAN with real flaws who makes real mistakes, but also has her good points.

On that note, if your issue with Dany is that she’s NOT a perfect hero stereotype, I cannot fathom how you handle the other characters on the show. Just look at them all…

Arya Stark doesn’t fit the “normal” mold of a lady, she’s into swords and murder and she’s off with the Faceless Men (and casually killing all of the Freys). Sansa Stark was the normal mold of a lady and she was the victim of those who abused and manipulated her, and she’s learnt from them (Littlefinger especially) in order to survive. Olenna Tyrell straight up poisoned Joff in order to get her granddaughter a better husband. The Sandsnakes murdered… a lot of people… because the Lannisters did terrible things to their family and House. Cersei blew up the Sept and murdered a crap ton of people because she wanted to protect her children and herself. Dany was stuck with an unstable older brother, raped, forced to marry etc. And later burnt a bunch of people and is still aiming to take her throne.

(A very basic run-down, lmao).

All of these women are morally grey. They’ve been through crap because they are real. They’ve done stupid things, necessary things, selfish things and terrible things. They are human. It’s the entire point of their characters. To be morally grey, to have flaws, to mess up.

If you don’t like Dany because she’s morally grey then I really don’t know who you like.

Jon Snow? He’s morally grey too.

Sansa? She’s morally grey too.

Literally anyone else? Morally grey too.

GRRM writes these characters as humans. That’s the entire point. If Dany were a cardboard cutout of your perfect hero, she would be boring and she would never have an issue. But she isn’t that. She is interesting and makes mistakes and has flaws. Dany is - as I sais in a post previously - idealistic to a fault. She freed the slaves of Meereen and suffered the consequences of those actions. If she were perfect, it would have been perfect. Surprise - it wasn’t. She ain’t perfect.

And that’s the other thing, Dany Stans…

Dany isn’t a perfect human being. If you agree with every decision she’s ever made and consider her to be the “true queen” and that she’s never made a mistake because she’s perfect… you are missing the point, too.

She is not perfect, no one is, and she isn’t written to be. We’re not meant to agree with her fully or to love her unconditionally.

Personally, I have conflicting feelings about Dany. I used to be rather Anti, and was convinced that she would end up as the Mad Queen. But recently, I have come to really appreciate the “morally grey/ambiguous” way that GRRM has written Dany and everyone else. I don’t love Dany but I don’t hate her.

So, point of the post: Morally grey is okay.

Shitting on Dany for being morally grey is shitting on effective, complex storytelling and character development. And that’s the TEA.

Cersei blew up the Sept and murdered a crap ton of people because she wanted to protect her children and herself. Dany was stuck with an unstable older brother, raped, forced to marry etc. And later burnt a bunch of people and is still aiming to take her throne.

(A very basic run-down, lmao).

All of these women are morally grey. They’ve been through crap because they are real. They’ve done stupid things, necessary things, selfish things and terrible things. They are human. It’s the entire point of their characters. To be morally grey, to have flaws, to mess up.

If you don’t like Dany because she’s morally grey then I really don’t know who you like.

Jon Snow? He’s morally grey too.

Sansa? She’s morally grey too.

Literally anyone else? Morally grey too.

GRRM writes these characters as humans. That’s the entire point. If Dany were a cardboard cutout of your perfect hero, she would be boring and she would never have an issue. But she isn’t that. She is interesting and makes mistakes and has flaws. Dany is - as I sais in a post previously - idealistic to a fault. She freed the slaves of Meereen and suffered the consequences of those actions. If she were perfect, it would have been perfect. Surprise - it wasn’t. She ain’t perfect.

And that’s the other thing, Dany Stans…

Dany isn’t a perfect human being. If you agree with every decision she’s ever made and consider her to be the “true queen” and that she’s never made a mistake because she’s perfect… you are missing the point, too.

She is not perfect, no one is, and she isn’t written to be. We’re not meant to agree with her fully or to love her unconditionally.

Personally, I have conflicting feelings about Dany. I used to be rather Anti, and was convinced that she would end up as the Mad Queen. But recently, I have come to really appreciate the “morally grey/ambiguous” way that GRRM has written Dany and everyone else. I don’t love Dany but I don’t hate her.

So, point of the post: Morally grey is okay.

Shitting on Dany for being morally grey is shitting on effective, complex storytelling and character development. And that’s the TEA.

summary: What Comes After the Flames
body:
What Comes After the Flames

The crackle of the fire. A shift of a log. Instinct moves his eyes downward to the flames.

In the hearth the golden lovers danced together. Strength moved them, their beauty calling wanderers to their song. Snapping and breaking the wood that fed them. Eventually the fuel would crumble. The lovers would burn too brightly, too strongly, shattering the source that gave them life. Nothing but ash would remain. Gray and black would be the only memory of such a fantastic dance, sprinkling the ground with a blanket of death.

The wind outside swirled around them, encasing the truth to the occupants of the small room. His gray eyes remained fixed on the embers, twirling in their ignorance, a twisted celebration of their own death. And it was coming. Surely death was coming.

The envy that filled him tasted like steel, a sharp slash, cutting a hole across his leather. Hunching over, his arms came about his torso, trying to hold himself together. Instead, his entrails poured out from between his fingers, the very essence of his life splattered on the floor.

A moan, low and guttural came from some person near him, but he heard nothing. The fire was roaring in his ears, mixing with the ice that pelted the gray stone of the castle.

And then there were arms, hands and fingers grasping for him. They worked, desperately trying to mold the shattered pieces of him into something convenient.

Violet eyes spoke, “A consort.”

The face that had always looked like him, “Ours,” she growled. “Still ours.”

The white eyes, distant and vacant, “Now you know the truth.”

Others, nameless eyes that meant nothing to him:

“Prince.”

“Warrior.”

“Ruler.”

He pushed the hands off of him. His body bled from the remembered knives, once again finding himself cradled in the freezing snow. All alone he looked up at the darkness of the sky. The second time was easier, surrendering his life to emptiness of the void.

The flames mocked him, the unity of their song a beautiful mirage that wouldn’t last the long night. This was his life. This was his legacy.

Not a Snow.

Not a Stark.

Fire.

There was only fire.

.

.

.

And then from out of the ashes, somehow still growing, subtle but strong, a winter rose. She had been silent, not interjecting until she found him alone.

Blue, like the frost were her eyes, “A wolf by your father or mother. Still a wolf,” she whispered near the dying embers.

“Still the sword in the darkness, though not my brother, you are mine. Always mine.”

And in the quiet, after the flames, it wasn’t the brokenness and ash that covered his reborn heart.

It was the unexpected softness that had grown from the roots of home, blossoming and blooming into a pillar of constancy.

After the flames, there wasn’t death after all, but life.

And she was radiant.

title:
Chapter 7 | Christian Hockey Sticks
        |
        Minnesota, State Of...
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
“Let’s see that slapshot!” Rickon yelled, passing her the puck. Sansa wound up, making contact with as much force as she could muster. The puck went wide by a huge margin, but it hit the boards with a satisfying clap, making Rickon’s laughter echo throughout the building. “Clap bomb!”

“The next Shea Weber.” Sansa laughed as Rickon retrieved the puck and turned to start his assault anew on Sandor.

“Is this how you win games?” Sandor demanded, skating backwards, trying to defend him. “Sheer speed?”

“The game has changed, old man,” Rickon chirped and Sandor growled, lunging for Rickon. Sansa gasped when he caught Rickon around the knees and lifted him up off the ice. Rickon shouted and began to protest between bouts of laughter.

“Don’t hurt each other.” Sansa winced, watching as Rickon attempted to get Sandor into a headlock.

“Your sister worries too much,” Sandor told Rickon, as he sat him atop the goal.

“Yeah, we tell her that a lot,” Rickon said wisely, kicking his feet slightly. Sandor turned to Sansa, tossing his stick aside, a glint in his grey eyes and Sansa froze.

“No, don’t—” She tried to object but when he started skating for her, she shrieked and tried to make a break for it, dropping her stick. It was futile; he had longer strides than her, and he was a professional hockey player to boot. She hadn’t even made it to the blue line when he caught up to her. He swept her off her feet, coasting as he hefted her, adjusting so that she fit better in his arms.
